1.brief: thou and thee, or (plural) ye and you
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
ruddy i.e. a human being (an individual or the species, mankind, etc.)
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement
a knife or razor (as making bare); also a scabbard (as being bare, i.e. empty)
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
to cross over; used very widely of any transition (literal or figurative; transitive, intransitive, intensive, causative); specifically, to cover (in copulation)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
the head (as most easily shaken), whether literal or figurative (in many applications, of place, time, rank, itc.)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
(only in the dual) a pair of scales
to be smooth (figuratively); by implication (as smooth stones were used for lots) to apportion or separate

2.brief: third; feminine athird (part); by extension, a third (day, year or time); specifically, a third-story cell)
flame; hence (in the plural) the East (as being the region of light)
to kindle, i.e. consume (by fire or by eating);  to be(-come) brutish
a bisection, i.e. (by implication) the centre
a city (a place guarded by waking or a watch) in the widest sense (even of a mere encampment or post)
to fill or (intransitively) be full of, in a wide application (literally and figuratively)
a day (as the warm hours), whether literal (from sunrise to sunset, or from one sunset to the next), or figurative (a space of time defined by an associated term), (often used adverb)
something hemming in, i.e. (objectively) a mound (of besiegers), (abstractly) a siege, (figuratively) distress; or (subjectively) a fastness
to take (in the widest variety of applications)
properly, self (but generally used to point out more definitely the object of a verb or preposition, even or namely)

to strike (lightly or severely, literally or figuratively)

(as noun) a circle, neighbour, or environs; but chiefly (as adverb, with or without preposition) around

to toss about; by implication, to diffuse, winnow

to pour out (literally or figuratively), i.e. empty

there (transferring to time) then; often thither, or thence
a little or few (often adverbial or compar.)
a number, definite (arithmetical) or indefinite (large, innumerable; small, a few); also (abstractly) narration
